name: sweet corn production | sweet corn | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/28562/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of Sweet Corn (fresh matter) in the US state of Florida  at farm, with an at harvest moisture content of 76.%. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. Residues are not collected but remain on the field post-harvest and overwinter.;The average yield of Sweet Corn grown in Florida for the 2014-2021 seasons was 14,104 kg/ha (wet mass) (USDA NASS (2022a)).  The dataset reflects the average Sweet Corn produced in Florida from 2014 to 2021, inclusive, as that period allows for at least one value from USDA statistics for most parameters and generally three or more.  Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices (0% no till, 0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage) (EPA 2022; IPM center 2003; IPM center 1997 data) and being grown in rotations with other vegetable crops. While genetically engineered sweet (fresh) corn seed is available, the share of sweet (fresh) corn grown from genetically engineered seed is not compiled; it is estimated that between 75 and 90% of North American sweet corn is conventional (USDA 2018b).;Area, productivity, use of mineral and organic fertilisers and pesticides, and irrigation inputs are based on farmer data reported to the U.S. Department of Agriculture where possible or budgets available for the state, unless otherwise noted. USDA NASS does not include fertilizer application data for Florida, so this dataset uses calculated values based on nutrient uptake rates. USDA NASS withholds pesticide application data for Florida, so this dataset uses estimated values based on other states and Florida guidance. Field operations and equipment types and fuel use are based on materials provided to growers by the agricultural extension office(s), including farm budgets, and on survey information agricultural extension office(s) collect from growers, in conjunction with row spacing data from USDA.  8.3% of crop land has installed drainage (tile or ditch), based on state-level agricultural survey data from USDA.  Irrigation is included based on share of crop irrigated (56.7% over the time period, USDA NASS (2018d)).;Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Florida decreased by 4% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020); USDA NASS does not report cropped area for Sweet Corn prior to 2016. The ecoinvent practice and associated crop LCI tool allocate land use change to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years in the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase; crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits. Thus, the amount of Land use change, annual crop is close to zero for Sweet Corn grown in Florida.;Soil characteristics, including pH, are based on distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. No anti-erosion practices are assumed in the dataset; instead, the erosion soil loss reported in the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's Natural Resource Inventory is used.;References:;USDA NASS (2022a) Area, Production, Yield by State - Sweet Corn - 2016-2022. US Department of Agriculture (USDA) National Agricultural Statistics Service. https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov (direct query: https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/results/5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC);USDA NASS (2018b) Statistical Methodology Name of Survey: Agricultural Resource Management Survey (ARMS) Phase II: PeanutProduction Practices Report, CornProduction Practices Report, and Soybean Production Practices Cost Report. US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Surveys/Guide_to_NASS_Surveys/Chemical_Use/2018_Peanuts_Soybeans_Corn/Statistical%20Methodology%202018.pdf;IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/MDcorn-sweet.pdf;IPM center (2003) Crop Profile for Sweet Corn in the North Central United States. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center.Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/us-ncr-sweetcorn.pdf;EPA (2022) Assessment of the Benefits of Atrazine and the Impacts of Potential Mitigation for Field Corn, Sweet Corn, Sorghum, and Sugarcane; PC Code (080803). (MEMORANDUM).US Environmental Protection Agency. https://downloads.regulations.gov/EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0266-1624/content.pdf;USDA NASS (2018d) 2018 Irrigation and Water Management Survey  (2017 Census of Agriculture).US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Online_Resources/Farm_and_Ranch_Irrigation_Survey/index.php;NRCS (2020) Land Cover/use of non-Federal rural land, by State and year, in the 2017 National Resources Inventory. This dataset includes cultivation of the field prior to planting, field treatments, planting, applications of nutrients and pesticides, and harvest. It ends with harvested sweet corn at the farm gate, prior to storage.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The valid period covers  2014-01-01 through 2021-12-31 based on primary data sources.  The production volumes, areas and applications are covered by data throughout the time period (annual for production and area, alternate years for applications). Because the specific pesticides used show time-dependent trends, the most recent 2 years of data are used to avoid underweighting the most dominant pesticides currently used and to avoid skewing  impacts based on compounds no longer in use. Field operations are based on enterprise crop budgets and other guidance and change little year to year.  Detailed guidance or enterprise crop budgets are not available for Florida sweet corn, so this dataset assumed field operations as detail in the enterprise crop budget for sweet corn from Clemson Extension (2020). The data presented here is aligned with Florida guidance from 2002 and 1997 and thus assumed valid for the dataset.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Production of Sweet Corn in Florida (US-FL).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset reflects current practice for Sweet Corn in Florida as of 2022.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Specific fertilisers are extrapolated from mineral fertiliser applications to  Sweet Corn in Florida and market consumption in the US (IFA 2020).  
 Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices. Detailed guidance or enterprise crop budgets are not available for Florida sweet corn, so this dataset assumed field operations as detail in the enterprise crop budget for sweet corn from Clemson Extension (2020). The data presented here is aligned with Florida guidance from 2002 and 1997 and thus assumed valid for the dataset.  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Machine sizes (power) are approximate but based on common, recent surveys and equipment analyses (Lazarus 2020).  
 Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011, available at ) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines and the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. Soil characteristics, including pH and clay content, are extrapolated from  distribution of soil pH sampling results reported in the 2020 Soil Test Summary (Bruulsema and Jones 2021). The share of acidic soils is likely overestimated as more more frequent testing is to be expected on soils having needed lime and thus low pH soils are likely to be more represented amongst the collected samples. Drainage tile data from 2012 (reported to USDA for the 2012 agricultural census) is extrapolated as valid from that date through the rest of the time period of the dataset and the distribution of drainage is treated as homogenous for all field crops. 
 Because all pesticide data is withheld in NASS (denoted as "D" in the data, indicating a non-zero value withheld to preserve confidentiality), pesticide applications for Florida are extrapolated from Clemson Extension guidance for South Carolina (Clemson 2020). These values were compared to crop profile and IPM guidance information for Florida (Kanissery et al 2022, IPM 2002). 
Transports are modelled with standard distances.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data is obtained from state, county and national statistics, agricultural extension offices, and published literature. Data for production, yields, applications of NPKS fertilisers, applications of pesticides, row width, and irrigation (if any) was obtained from the US Dept of Agriculture's National Agricultural Statistics Service and in most cases provides high-quality data spanning the dataset time period. Field operations and energy use are from enterprise crop budgets provided by local agricultural extensions offices and their farmer survey data. Literature data is used where USDA and agricultural extension guidance and data are not available.

Pesticides are assumed to be ultimately 100% emitted to soil across all rotation patterns, based on assumption that all sweet corn acres are treated, and assuming that cultivation is conventional tillage as common practice for weed management (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997).Data reported a quantity of total insecticides/herbicides/fungicides applied in sweet corn is sometimes available even when many of the substances in the category are reported with a “D”. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted.

The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). Phosphorus emissions to surface water are based on the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006), but using state-specific data for agricultural land (not crop-specific). exchanges.description: Transformation of land for planting.  Land is under rotation with other annual crop production (~80% corn-soy, ~20% corn-corn, Socolar et al 2021). US NRCS data indicates that land is leaving agricultural production rather than being transitioned into it, thus the continuous flux to/from annual crop is effectively steady state. Annual production averaged  0.2  million tonnes from  2016-2021 on . million ha planted and . million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.709 ha/t or 7090.176 m2/t (0.7.09m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated ( 56.69% ) and non-irrigated ( 43.3% ) based on agricultural census data ( USDA NASS ) 4.02E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 3.07E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land

Phosphate leaching to ground water 0.14 kg PO4/ha (9.926E-6 kg/kg Sweet Corn): 7.E-2 kg PO4/ha from manure and 7.E-2 kg PO4/ha from leaching from arable land.  Phosphate leaching to ground water is calculated using the SALCA-P model (Prasuhn 2006) with an average leaching factor for arable lands and the amount of phosphate in any applied manure, as implemented in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (see Ecoinvent_Too_Model_Description_20191015.pdf). Does not incorporate state or county data on soils, slope or conservation drainage infrastructure. Calculated with the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool. If the slope is less than 3%, no phosphate loss through run-off occurs (Prasuhn 2006). If the slope is greater or equal to 3%, phosphate loss through run-off are computed like in (Prasuhn 2006) with the site-specific correction factors set to their default value (=1):

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. CO2 emissions from use of urea, fertilisers, and lime is 142.379 kg/ha (1.01E-2 kg/kg Sweet Corn): 115.95 kg/ha from lime and 26.43 kg/ha from urea and urea ammonium nitrate  (lime: 8.22E-3 kg/kg Sweet Corn; urea: 1.87E-3 kg/kg Sweet Corn). 
Emissions are calculated following the IPCC NIR Guidelines, §11.3 and §11.4, using IPCC NIR equations 11.12 (lime) and 11.13 (urea) (mass of lime/urea * emissions factor for lime/urea) with Tier 1 emissions factors (IPCC 2006b).  EF limestone = 0.12 kg CO2-C/kg limestone (0.06-0.12, uniform) and EF urea = 0.2 kg CO2-C/kg urea (0.1-0.2, uniform) applied to both urea and the approximately 35% of UAN that is urea. The result is converted from kg CO2-C to kg CO2 (multiplying by the molar mass of CO2/mass of C in CO2 = 44.01/12)

1.42E-4 ha/kg tillage, field cultivator (2. effective pass(es) per year). 
 Detailed guidance or enterprise crop budgets are not available for Florida sweet corn, so this dataset assumed field operations as detail in the enterprise crop budget for sweet corn from Clemson Extension (2020). The data presented here is aligned with Florida guidance from 2002 and 1997 and thus assumed valid for the dataset.
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices (0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage, and 0% no till, ).

exchanges.description:
1.00 ha/ha (7.09E-5 ha/kg Sweet Corn) fertilising, by injection
Guidance for sweet corn production in Florida is 1 pre-planting and 2 to 4 post-planting (sidedress) fertiliser applications (Bayabil H, Li Y, Olczyk T, Liu G 2022). This dataset assumes 1 preplant and 3 postplant, for a total of 4 applications, which is consitent with operations for other states. Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other N, because they are applied differently, with different equipment Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.99). Other N application is then total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=3.01). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 24.78%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.99 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.99 * 100.0% of crop area with applied N) and 3.01 other N applications via broadcast (3.01 * 100.0%). Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 3.01.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Clemson Extension 2020, Kanissery et al 2022, Liu et al 2022b, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.

The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%).  Detailed guidance or enterprise crop budgets are not available for Florida sweet corn, so this dataset assumed field operations as detail in the enterprise crop budget for sweet corn from Clemson Extension (2020). The data presented here is aligned with Florida guidance from 2002 and 1997 and thus assumed valid for the dataset.Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices (0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage, and 0% no till, ).

Annual production averaged  0.7  million tonnes from  2016-2021 on . million ha planted and . million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.428 ha/t or 4282.466 m2/t (0.4.282m2/kg). This overall land use is split into irrigated ( 86.64% ) and non-irrigated ( 13.4% ) based on agricultural census data ( USDA NASS ) 3.71E-1 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of irrigated land, and 5.72E-2 m2 planted/kg harvested maize of non-irrigated land

Emissions of heavy metals to soil are estimated based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The balance of heavy metal emissions to soils includes the net change from erosion, leaching, crop removal and fertilizer, manure, lime, planting and deposition.  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Heavy-metal contents of plant material, maize (mg/kg dry matter, from Freiermuth 2006). ; Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Deposition of heavy metals to soils, mg per ha per year (Freiermuth 2006). ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). state and regional erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). Annual production averaged  0.7  million tonnes from  2016-2021 on . million ha planted and . million ha harvested. Thus occupation is 0.428 ha/t or 4282.466 m2/t (0.4.282m2/kg). 5.00 ha/ha (3.55E-4 ha/kg Sweet Corn) fertilising, by broadcaster
Guidance for sweet corn production in Florida is 1 pre-planting and 2 to 4 post-planting (sidedress) fertiliser applications (Bayabil H, Li Y, Olczyk T, Liu G 2022). This dataset assumes 1 preplant and 3 postplant, for a total of 4 applications, which is consitent with operations for other states. Applications of N are split between anhydrous ammonia and other N, because they are applied differently, with different equipment Other than anhydrous ammonia, most NPK(S) fertilisers are applied together via broadcast application.
Anhydrous ammonia application (knifing/injection) is calculated as market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia * total N applications (=0.99). Other N application is then total USDA N applications less applications of anhydrous ammonia (=3.01). The market share of N that is anhydrous ammonia is calculated from fertiliser market group shares crossed with meeting NPKS nutrient demand (here, 24.78%). Thus, the dataset includes 0.99 anhydrous ammonia applications via injection (0.99 * 100.0% of crop area with applied N) and 3.01 other N applications via broadcast (3.01 * 100.0%). Since the number of passes for N application after removing the anhydrous ammonia share is greater than the maximum number of passes reported for the other nutrients, this dataset assumes that any other fertiliser applications are reflected under that pass and the total fertiliser broadcast fertiliser passes are thus 3.01.

Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted.  (Clemson Extension 2020, Kanissery et al 2022, Liu et al 2022b, Hanna, Mark 2016, Schuler and Frank 1998, Lattz and Schnitkey 2021b).  Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Where an operation applies only to a portion of the harvested area, the number of passes has been scaled by the % of harvested area to which it applies (e.g., manure spreading or insecticide) as indicated by USDA statistics (applications) or USDA reports (manure use) or as otherwise indicated in enterprise crop budgets.

exchanges.description: Emissions of heavy metals to ground water arise from leaching. These emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production).  The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils)Sources for heavy metals leaching to groundwater include: Leaching of heavy metals to groundwater (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where no drainage is installed ; the share of leaching to groundwater is calcualted from Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf.

Land use change is allocated to all crops and activities that grew in the last 20 years for the US, and only to them, according to their respective area increase. Crop production and natural land areas in all countries use data from 1989 to 2012 (FAOSTAT 2012), as well as for country climates and soil types (EU-JRC 2010c). Crops for which planted area decreased are not attributed LUC impacts or credits.  Total cropland land use, for all crops, in Florida decreased by 4% between 1997 and 2017 (NRCS 2020a); USDA NASS does not report cropped area for Sweet Corn prior to 2016. 
Land use change (LUC) combines land transformation areas calculated with the adapted 'Direct Land Use Change Assessment Tool' version 2014 developed by Blonk Consultants and the carbon losses from soil organic carbon (SOC) and vegetation (VEG) as calculated in ecoinvent v3. See 'WFLDB-Guidelines.pdf', available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports. Calculated value from ecoinvent Crop LCI tool, 0.15137 divided by the yield in kg/ha.

exchanges.description:
Beta-cyfluthrin emission to agricultural soil (1.560E-02 kg/ha).  Pesticides are assumed to be ultimately 100% emitted to soil across all rotation patterns, based on assumption that all sweet corn acres are treated, and assuming that cultivation is conventional tillage as common practice for weed management (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997).Data reported a quantity of total insecticides/herbicides/fungicides applied in sweet corn is sometimes available even when many of the substances in the category are reported with a “D”. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted.  
Sources: SWEETCORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021,https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/#5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC,IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. If this total is available, the amount remaining after the sum of substance-specific values is accounted for is divided equally among the substances reported with a “D”. If the sum of available values exceeds or equals the total reported, any remaining “D” substances are treated as zero and omitted.  
Sources: SWEETCORN - APPLICATIONS, MEASURED IN LB / ACRE / YEAR, AVG (fertilizer and pesticides, amount, number of applications) - 2000-2021,https://quickstats.nass.usda.gov/#5E5B411A-F9EF-3B83-AAFF-995DD89820FC,IPM center (1997) Crop Profile for Corn (Sweet) in Maryland. Southern Integrated Pest Management Center.Southern Integrated Pest Management Center. https://ipmdata.ipmcenters.org/documents/cropprofiles/us-ncr-sweetcorn.pdf ,EPA (2022) Assessment of the Benefits of Atrazine and the Impacts of Potential Mitigation for Field Corn, Sweet Corn, Sorghum, and Sugarcane; PC Code (080803). (MEMORANDUM).US Environmental Protection Agency. https://downloads.regulations.gov/EPA-HQ-OPP-2013-0266-1624/content.pdf

Emissions of heavy metals to surface water arise from leaching (when drainage is present) and erosion. Emissions are estimated  based on the SALCA-heavy metal model (Freiermuth 2006) following the procedure in the ecoinvent agricultural LCI tool (Faist Emmenegger, Délerce-Mauris and Porté 2018 Models Integrated in Ecoinvent LCI Calculation Tool for Crop Production). The crop system carries a share of heavy metals emissions based on the ratio of cropping additions to total additions (additions to crop system divided by additions to crop system plus depostion from air and present in soils) Sources for heavy metals contents include: Leaching of heavy metals to surface water (Wolfensberger & Dinkel 1997), where drainage is installed ; Average heavy metal contents in crop soils, mg per kg soil, based on data for Switzerland (from Keller & Desaules, 2001). erosion rates are from US NRC National Resources Inventory, 2017. and Drainage on all cropland acres state-wide, including tile drainage (4.2%,) and ditch drainage (5.1%). USDA (2018a) 2017 Census of Agriculture, Volume 1, Chapter 2: State Level Data - Table 41.  Land Use Practices:  2017 and 2012 (live table: https://www.nass.usda.gov/Quick_Stats/CDQT/chapter/2/table/41/state/US). US Department of Agriculture (USDA). https://www.nass.usda.gov/Publications/AgCensus/2017/Full_Report/Volume_1,_Chapter_2_US_State_Level/st99_2_0041_0041.pdf. Fertilizer, manure and pesticide application rates are based on USDA NASS data.

Each planted hectare uses 11.08 kg seed (7.86E-4 kg/kg Sweet Corn). This value is calculated from a seeding rate of 69,189 seeds/ha (Graham, C. and G. Carlson 2016; Turnipseed, B 2016) and an average seed count of 6,244 seeds/kg (averaged from commercial listings of F1 (SH2 and se-se) seeds, https://www.ufseeds.com/vegetables/corn/supersweet-sh2-corn, https://lacrosseseed.com/product-information/forage-tech-sheets/tech-sheets-alfalfa-5). While genetically engineered sweet (fresh) corn seed is available, the share of sweet (fresh) corn grown from genetically engineered seed is not compiled; it is estimated that between 75 and 90% of North American sweet corn is conventional (USDA 2018b). Seeding rates are based on state average guidance, not specifically for GE or conventional seed.  Germination and stand losses are accounted for in the seeding rate.

7.09E-5 ha/kg tillage, subsoiling, by subsoiler or v-ripper (1. effective pass(es) per year). 
Field operations are as identified in crop- and rotation-specific enterprise crop budgets supplied by the regional agricultural extension office and matched to equipment type in the budget or crop guidance unless otherwise noted. Operations are matched to equipment type and where multiple options are available, the share of each is determined from guidance and annual farmer survey data (Custom Rate Summaries) for contracted operations/equipment. Field cultivation and tillage operations are specific to the tillage regime used. Seed establishment and weed control for sweet corn generally require tillage (EPA 2022; IPM 2003, IPM 1997), so this dataset reflects sweet corn production using conventional tillage practices (0% reduced till, 100% conventional tillage, and 0% no till, ).
